{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-27261].
  {panel}

In a vast amount of pages, it is helpful to mark some as 'Obsolete' to allow readers to know what content is out of date and what is current. Right now we are utilizing one of two methods. 

A. Set label 'Obsolete' then Add Warnings macro with text 'Obsolete' 
or 
B. Set label 'Obsolete' then add Status macro with text 'Obsolete' 

You get the picture, it's redundant and prone to error. What I would like to see is a macro that I can place on the page that looks at the labels and reacts to their content. 

Workflow would be like this. 

1. Setup macro with 'Obsolete' as the trigger word, and coloring for background as well (think Status macro color settings) - Add macro
2. Add label 'Obsolete' 
3. Save page - on load, the page will then display the status where ever I placed the macro

If later someone comes behind, updates the page, and removes the label... the page will hide the status.
fields.summary: Label sets status

fields.description:
The Arabic language is read in reverse to Western languages such as English, meaning that instead of being read from left-right, (as with English), Arabic is read from right-left.

Confluence handles Arabic script without problems and can display the correct behavior on the page, but the PDF Export function in Confluence exports Arabic script the wrong way around, (treating it as if it should be read from left-right), making it bizarre and unreadable for Arabic speakers.

A screenshot from the page with the expected output and a PDF with the actual output is attached to this ticket for comparison.

Using the PDF CSS customization attribute "direction: RTL" will also not help in this case.

As the export to Word works as expected, the potential workaround can be to export the page to Word and then save it as a PDF.
fields.summary: Export to PDF reverses the content of Arabic and Hebrew script

# When nobody checks on that for an X period of time (that could be configurable by the Space Admin for all Space pages) then my page goes automatically out-of-date.
# Visually, that means that my page title or a dedicated area turns light and then dark red. When the page gets specifically "updated" then that area turns green (or white). That will make it really easy for the user to know when a page is being maintained or not.
fields.summary: As a User, I'd like to have some visual way of our pages that are not up to date

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-27211].
  {panel}

Problem can arrise if Confluence has the incorrect, or at least inconsistent case sensitivity in the database.  Add an operation as part of the startup task that check case sensitivity in the database and compares it with 1) recommend configurations 2) previous startups.  Throwing an error message instead of starting up as usual will reduce if not eliminate the problems of Case Inconsistency.

This KB explains well the situation:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFKB/Confluence+Does+Not+Start+with+%27MySQL+session+isolation+level+%27REPEATABLE-READ%27+is+no+longer+supported%27+Message
(See screen shot)

The error is clear, however, it doesn't tell what are the next steps.

The page should contain a link to the appropriate section of the MySQL DB settings so that the correct isolation level can be set.
fields.summary: Confluence Should Check to See That Database Has the Correct Case Sensitivity Set.

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-27198].
  {panel}

Currently, a subfolder with pageid is created in _$confluence-home/thumbnails_ folder for thumbnails of a given page. This leads to this folder having X subfolders where X is the number of pages having at least one thumbnail.

Unfortunatly, even linux cannot handle more than 32.000 subfolders per folder. Thus, even on linux one Confluence instance cannot have more than 32.000 pages with thumbnails.

In our environment having more than 150.000 (current) pages, we have been hitting this limit several times now.

Ok, we can manually remove the contents of the _/thumbnails_ folder from time to time. However, I'd prefer a solution such that there is no such limit with respect to number of pages having thumbnails.
fields.summary: Allow creating thumbnails for more than 32.000 pages

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-27194].
  {panel}

The keyboard shortcut help is nice (accessible via the ? button), but there are some keyboard shortcuts which are handy but not listed.

I want to be able to edit the text that is displayed there, but there is currently no *easy* way to do so. (yes, I could probably extract an html file from some jar and fix it, but I don't want to).

It occurred to me that it would be nice if *all* help text in the system were available as wiki pages that the administrator could edit. That way, we could edit the text using the same editor that we've gotten used to with confluence and use it to update the pages.

Naturally, that would make upgrading more difficult - if the help page has changed, what to do? Use the new help page, or the customized page? I would say replace the customized page with the new page, and leverage the page history to get back any edits the administrator may have made.

Also, in case the admin messes up a page, there should be a big button which says "use default text" so that they can revert the help text back to what it was.

This is very similar to how JSPWiki does its help - all pages displayed to the user are editable wiki pages. It's simple and powerful.
fields.summary: Make help pages editable wiki pages

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# Setup Confluence
# Shut down Confluence

Expected behaviour: Plugin framework should be shut down (look for "{{INFO [main] [atlassian.plugin.manager.DefaultPluginManager] shutdown Shutting down the plugin system}}" in the logs)
Actual behaviour: Plugin framework is not shut down

A side-effect of not shutting down plugin framework properly is that plugins that have created non-terminating user threads will keep JVM alive indefinitely.

This should probably be fixed by removing {{frameworkStarted}} check from {{PluginFrameworkContextListener}} and creating {{PluginFrameworkLifecycleManager}} that would be responsible for managing the state of the plugin framework. Some of the lifecycle specific code from {{ConfluencePluginManager}} should be moved to {{PluginFrameworkLifecycleManager}} as well.
fields.summary: Plugin framework is not shut down when shutting down Confluence after setup

*Problem Description*
If you type in {{[test|urllink]}} in Confluence editor, it will be converted to link. If the link didn't exist, it will be rendered as red color. Otherwise, it will be like normal link which is blue in color with underline.

*Steps to reproduce*
# Go to Confluence editor by adding new page or editing page.
# If you type {{[Test|urllink]}} it will be converted to link
# If you type {{[Tëst|urllink]}}, it won't be converted to link

fields.description:
*Description*:
The show/hide side bar in Confluence documentation theme, it should remember the cookies and last settings to be shown when logged in to the page again.

*Steps to reproduce*:
- In fireball 183, navigate to Confluence and go to any space with documentation theme, and click to show the sidebar. 
- Logout, and login in again, and navigate to the same space.
- You will find that the sidebar setting is reset to hide.

The cookies responsible to keep this setting "*doc-sidebar*" is reset to 0 on the content value, and doesn't keep the setting before logout.
fields.summary: Show/Hide sidebar in Confluence is not retained by cookies
